item.title: R to @fede_intern: one concrete example of this is the amount of people of the >@PrivacyScaling team that didnt or don’t like STARKs and never even looked at it. gladly this is changing but it was obvious that hash based was the way to go and just for academic/politics nobody was looking into it or building things with it. Hopefully now this is changing but this is being repeated in other verticals.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description: one concrete example of this is the amount of people of the @PrivacyScaling team that didnt or don’t like STARKs and never even looked at it. gladly this is changing but it was obvious that hash based was the way to go and just for academic/politics nobody was looking into it or building things with it. Hopefully now this is changing but this is being repeated in other verticals.

item.title:
The problem the EF has is very simple: most of the people involved never created a company, they don’t know how to prioritize or how to communicate. Most are researchers. They never had a tight feedback loop between what gets decided and their output. The problem it has is not due to the fact that it’s a foundation or that Ethereum is a protocol and not a company. It’s related to how prioritization is done.
I love Ethereum focus on decentralization and ZK. However it’s clear to me that even if the people involved are smart, it doesn’t have the incentives to improve in core critical areas like marketing or to solve product related problems.
This doesn’t mean I don’t like the EF or many of the people in charge. Many do great work but it’s becoming obvious there is a problem. Long term this will become a clearer problem that if it doesn’t get address it will limit the speed at which Ethereum grows.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern

It’s related to how prioritization is done.

I love Ethereum focus on decentralization and ZK. However it’s clear to me that even if the people involved are smart, it doesn’t have the incentives to improve in core critical areas like marketing or to solve product related problems.

This doesn’t mean I don’t like the EF or many of the people in charge. Many do great work but it’s becoming obvious there is a problem. Long term this will become a clearer problem that if it doesn’t get address it will limit the speed at which Ethereum grows.

item.title:
One of the best books you can read. It’s old and not everything is relevant but you will learn a lot. Hacking the art of exploitation I’ve been recommending since 2008/9 too.
At some point I’m gonna write a new version of these books to update them.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: Want to play with Simplex?
@commonwarexyz released an open (MIT/Apache-2), Rust-based implementation a few weeks ago:
https://docs.rs/commonware-consensus/latest/commonware_consensus/simplex/index.html
You can read more about it here:
https://commonware.xyz/blogs/commonware-the-anti-framework.html#:~:text=Commonware%3A%20Now%20Including%20Consensus
item.dc:creator: @_patrickogrady

item.title: If you need an introduction to distributed systems I recommend you first read Understanding Distributed Systems by @RaVitillo then Data Intensive Applications and Database internals.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:

item.title:
Lambda is working on a few blog post that will explain different consensus algorithms. From Raft and Paxos to Tendermint, Hotstuff and Simplex.
I highly recommend you read about Simplex. It's simple and clear.

item.title:

Lambda will start using more it's designers for things like this. Great work Nous.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: you will obviously hear bad things. there are incentives for that to happen. that’s not a very substantial argument as you might imagine. i’m open to debate publicly about codebases with whoever wants to. i’ve seen too many 🙈.
to start with: 25k lines of code counting dependencies that we implemented versus reth with 250k lines of code without the dependencies. that’s a concrete metric. lines of codes has a linear relationship with bugs and security problems.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
you will obviously hear bad things. there are incentives for that to happen. that’s not a very substantial argument as you might imagine. i’m open to debate publicly about codebases with whoever wants to. i’ve seen too many 🙈.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: this year ends exactly the way i imagined it would
an ai agent takes over 65% of ct mindshare, gets psyopsed by udi to shill our bags and udi topblasts the ai agent back to the cheer of the crowds
perfectly normal thanks 2024 see you in 2025
